awd_titl_txt: An Analysis of the Discovery of RNA Splicing with a Focus on Epistemic and Social Justice
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a research project that will provide a history of the discovery of RNA splicing. The researcher will address a lacuna in the historiography of molecular biology by increasing its analytical content on RNA, which has long remained overshadowed by a preponderance of historical and social science research on DNA, genomics, and proteomics. In doing so, she will examine the impact of gender, ethnicity, and age bias thereby offering further clarification of the persisting underrepresentation of women and minorities in science; she will do so by documenting how those participants were deprived of epistemic justice, even when they played an indispensable role in a major discovery in one of four key labs. Project results will be disseminated via presentations at pertinent professional society meetings. They will also be the subject of a monograph which documents and compares the actual history of those who participated in the discovery as co-authors (whether woman, foreign, junior, or senior scientist) in one of the four labs. Results will also be posted on a blog, which provides crowd sourcing opportunities and links to high traffic websites. In addition, the researcher will collaborate with a playwright to write and produce a play inspired by her research results; the play will articulate the intertwined moral dilemmas of scientific progress and social justice.

The researcher will use historical and sociological methods including archival research on the personal papers and institutional records of deceased co-authors, in-depth oral history with surviving co-authors, sociological analysis of collaborative publication patterns pursued by various co-author categories, historical ethnography of anniversary events (such as conferences held to mark the 40th anniversary of this discovery), and content analysis of scientific publications (largely though not entirely from the 1970s).The project further utilizes the 40th anniversary of this discovery to collect new sources of historical value including manuscripts, correspondence, photographs, and autobiographical reflections. The project will stimulate STS scholars to engage in refined studies of power relations in science, while empowering policy makers in their efforts to ensure greater transparency in the reward system of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project researched the origins of the discovery of RNA splicing, (1977) one of the most important discoveries in molecular biology, in the scientific, historical, and social context of the 1970s.  The project focused on the glaring issue of epistemic injustice in the allocation of credit for this discovery. Woman scientists who played a key role, as evident from their position as lead co-authors, were marginalized and excluded from recognition. The 1993 Nobel prize recognizing this discovery was given to two male lab directors whose contributions cannot be dissociated from those of their collaborative co-authors.

Specific project outcomes include the following: (#1-10; unless otherwise specified, each item refers to two dozen co-authors, six of them women, belonging to half a dozen collaborative teams of 2-5 scientists each. All these teams claimed the discovery via publications in the second half of 1977, but only two of these teams gained recognition as ?discoverers? by virtue of providing the visual ?discovery proof?. Hence, the seven co-authors of these two teams received special attention.

1)    Oral history interviews: conducted with all surviving co-authors, this unique material includes recording, transcribing, and analyzing the perspective of each scientist co-author, with special emphasis upon the perspectives of the lead co-authors and lab directors of each team.

2)    Archival research: Personal Papers of deceased co-authors, and their deceased mentors, were located, scanned, and analyzed.

3)    Publication analysis: pertinent publications covering the decade 1974-84 were collected and analyzed in terms of  dates of publication, submission, and revision; type of journal, co-authors information, and key findings.

4)    Biographical analysis:  the careers of all the co-authors were evaluated and compared on the basis of collected CVs which include information on education, career patterns, and recognition received for one?s scientific work. The project further documented various limitations of the reward system in science, while focusing on the Nobel nomination and selection process for the 1993 award in Physiology or Medicine, given for this discovery. The project also noted (in publication #8/c below) its uncritical coverage in the scientific and other media.

5)    Institutional analysis: the scientific institutions to which the discovery co-authors belonged at the time of the discovery were compared in terms of leadership, size, technological and human resources, and diversity policies on gender and race. (in alphabetical order: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory , NY; MIT Cancer Research Center in Cambridge, MA.; National Cancer Institute of NIH in Bethesda, MD.; Rockefeller University in NYC;  and the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel.

6)    Gender and race analysis: The project documented the gender bias experienced by the woman co-authors, as well as the impact of intersectionality of gender and race bias experienced by woman co-authors of color; two of the six woman co-authors were women of color. (of East and South Asian descent)

7)    Image analysis: photographic images of co-author woman and man scientists, their interaction with lab colleagues, scientific instruments, and diagrams capturing the ?discovery proof? were analyzed as visual evidence. Of special interest is the collective portrait of six woman scientists, (attached) which enjoyed wide diffusion beyond the PI?s article ( see below, #8/a) in which it first appeared. (E.g. in other articles, letters to the Editor, blogs, and NSF news items) Publication #8/c focused on the collective portrait?s construction of women as gendered professionals at a time their entry into scientific careers was  new.

8)    Publications by the PI:

a)    Abir-Am, P. G. ?The Women who Discovered RNA Splicing?. American Scientist vol. 108, issue 5 (September-October 2020): 298-305. (https://www.americanscientist.org/article/the-women-who-discovered-rna-splicing) This journal has a wide distribution, (c. 100.000) with a pass along factor of 1.8. It received the Society for Information Industry and Associations (SIIA) Excel 2021 award for a featured article. It also served as the subject of a NSF?s blog (8/10/21) and a NSF news report. (9/23/21)

b-e) See Abir-Am 2021, 2024a,b, and 2025 in the FPR section on publications resulting from this project.

9) Conference presentations:

-   International Society for the History, Philosophy and Social Studies of Biology;

(2019/Oslo-Norway; 2021/ Cold Spring Harbor, NY-USA; 2023/ Toronto-Canada)

-       History of Science Society Annual Meetings; (2018/Seattle-USA; 2022/Chicago-USA; 2023/Portland, OR.-USA)

-       Society for Social Studies of Science Annual Meeting, 2022/ Prague-Czech Republic; 2023/Honolulu-USA;

-       European Society for the History of Science, 2020/Turin-Italy; 2022/Brussels-Belgium;

-       Israeli Society for History, Philosophy and Sociology of Science, 2019/Jerusalem; 2023/Tel Aviv.

-       AAAS (American Association for the Advancement of Science), 2017/ Boston-MA.; 2024/Denver, CO.

1)     Student training: A dozen students, mostly junior and senior women from Brandeis University, participated in the project as research assistants. They were treained in  conducting oral history, sociological analysis of scientific careers, analysis of gender and race bias, and analysis of scientific publications in molecular biology. The students? diversity included cultural backgrounds  pertinent to this project, USA, Taiwan, India, and Israel; other students came  from Kenya and Turkuia. (Turkey)
